**NetHack 3.0.6** is the eleventh public release of [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack") and the seventh by the [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam"). [Izchak Miller](/wiki/Izchak_Miller "Izchak Miller") published it to the [Usenet](/wiki/Usenet "Usenet") newsgroup comp.sources.games and the moderator approved it in November 1989.

[ ]

## Availability

The original Usenet posts are available from the Internet Archive, and are linked from [this list of URLs](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.6/URL_list "NetHack 3.0.6/URL list").

[Ali Harlow](/wiki/Ali_Harlow "Ali Harlow")[\[1\]](http://www.juiblex.co.uk/nethack/front.html) has a NetHack 3.0.6 distribution at [\[2\]](http://www.juiblex.co.uk/nethack/source/nethack-3.0.6.tar.gz).

## Significant changes

The NetHack 3.0 series is notable for its frequent releases, and NetHack 3.0.6 came out only weeks after [NetHack 3.0.5](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.5 "NetHack 3.0.5"). This is perhaps because [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0") so vastly expanded the game that it contained many bugs.

Notable new features include:

- The [MS-DOS](/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS") port now has support for overlays, allowing a full-featured game on MS-DOS for the first time in the 3.0 era.

* Open doors have different symbols from closed ones.

- Doors may be entered and exited diagonally. (Given how this interacts with shops, it seems likely to have disappeared rather quickly.)

* Food may be eaten off the floor, and you no longer necessarily resume eating an interrupted meal.

- Wielding non-weapons no longer grants intrinsics.

* A new option, CLIPPING, allows playing on small windows.

- The multiple demons are now controlled by INFERNO rather than HARD. Other features (not detailed here) are still controlled by HARD.

* The / command now takes configurable characters into account.

- Leprechauns switch letters with liches, and nymphs with nagas, so the more formidable monsters get the uppercase letters.

* New monsters are [tiger](/wiki/Tiger "Tiger"), [grid bug](/wiki/Grid_bug "Grid bug"), [newt](/wiki/Newt "Newt"), [gecko](/wiki/Gecko "Gecko"), [iguana](/wiki/Iguana "Iguana"), [lizard](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard"), and [crocodile](/wiki/Crocodile "Crocodile"). The [lizard corpse](/wiki/Lizard_corpse "Lizard corpse") is no longer a distinct random object, but is obtained by killing a lizard.

- There is one new object, a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn").

* Drawbridges are improved.

- Still more bug fixes.

## The adventurer

The player may choose from these roles:

| Role                                              | Alignment |
| ------------------------------------------------- | --------- |
| [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") | Lawful    |
| [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian")          | Chaotic   |
| [Cave-(wo)man](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman")           | Lawful    |
| [Elf](/wiki/Elf_\(role\) "Elf (role)")            | Lawful    |
| [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer")                   | Lawful    |
| [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                   | Lawful    |
| [Priest(ess)](/wiki/Priest "Priest")              | Neutral   |
| [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                      | Chaotic   |
| [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")                | Lawful    |
| [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")                | Neutral   |
| [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie")             | Chaotic   |
| [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                   | Neutral   |

All classes permit male and female adventurers, except the Valkyrie which must be female.

The adventurer has [experience](/wiki/Experience "Experience"), [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points"), [magical energy](/wiki/Magical_energy "Magical energy"), [armor class](/wiki/Armor_class "Armor class"), [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment"), and the six major [attributes](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute"). He may advance to [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 30.

The initial [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") is a little [dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog") for Cavemen, a [kitten](/wiki/Kitten "Kitten") for Wizards, and a random choice of the two for all others.

## Dungeon features

The dungeon in NetHack 3.0.6 has no branches; there is one way up and one way down. The first 25 levels or so consist of rooms, and beyond that, the adventurer encounters the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") and then mazes. The deepest dungeon level is 50.

[Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa") appears as @ on the down-stairs of the level before the Castle. She does not have a special level, and is thus a snare for the unwary adventurer.

Dungeon levels below the Castle are designated as "[Hell](/wiki/Hell "Hell")". Entering hell without [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance"), or losing it once there, is an [instadeath](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath"). This may happen by taking off an item that confers fire resistance ([ring of fire resistance](/wiki/Ring_of_fire_resistance "Ring of fire resistance") or red [dragon scale mail](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail")), losing one's [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"), or by being hit by a [gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin"). One may still be saved if he has some other source of fire resistance. These levels have only up-stairs, and the only way to proceed beyond the first level after the Castle is by [level teleportation](/wiki/Level_teleportation "Level teleportation").

[Special rooms](/wiki/Special_room "Special room") are:

- [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room")
- [swamp](/wiki/Swamp "Swamp")
- [vault](/wiki/Vault "Vault")
- [beehive](/wiki/Beehive "Beehive")

- [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar")

Traps are:

- monsters disguised as [statues](/wiki/Statue "Statue")
- [bear trap](/wiki/Bear_trap "Bear trap")
- [arrow trap](/wiki/Arrow_trap "Arrow trap")
- [dart trap](/wiki/Dart_trap "Dart trap")
- [trapdoor](/wiki/Trapdoor "Trapdoor")
- [teleportation trap](/wiki/Teleportation_trap "Teleportation trap")
- [pit](/wiki/Pit "Pit")
- [sleeping gas trap](/wiki/Sleeping_gas_trap "Sleeping gas trap")
- [magic trap](/wiki/Magic_trap "Magic trap")
- [squeaky board](/wiki/Squeaky_board "Squeaky board")
- [web](/wiki/Web "Web")
- [spiked pit](/wiki/Spiked_pit "Spiked pit")
- [level teleporter](/wiki/Level_teleporter "Level teleporter")
- [anti-magic field](/wiki/Anti-magic_field "Anti-magic field")
- [rust trap](/wiki/Rust_trap "Rust trap")
- [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap")
- [land mine](/wiki/Land_mine "Land mine")

The [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor") is found in the possession of the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") in a maze level. He is in a small room in the center of the maze, surrounded by water and accompanied by a [hell hound](/wiki/Hell_hound "Hell hound") and a [vampire lord](/wiki/Vampire_lord "Vampire lord").

Fake Wizard rooms contain a random [demon prince](/wiki/Demon_prince "Demon prince") instead of the Wizard and a fake Amulet. If all demon princes have appeared, a demon lord appears instead; if all demon lords have appeared, the room contains a random ordinary demon. All eight modern named demons exist, but their modern lairs do not.

A [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing") is guaranteed in the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"), in its modern position; but it lies exposed on the floor instead of being protected by a [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") and [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth").

When ascending from level 1 with the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor"), one is transported immediately to the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Endgame_\(3.0\) "Endgame (3.0)"); the [Elemental Planes](/wiki/Elemental_Planes "Elemental Planes") do not yet exist. The Astral Plane is different from the modern game, having mazes and powerful monsters instead of the denizens of the modern version.

NetHack 3.0.6 is the eleventh public release of NetHack and the seventh by the DevTeam. Izchak Miller published it to the Usenet newsgroup comp.sources.games and the moderator approved it in November 1989.

Contents

  • 1 Availability
  • 2 Significant changes
  • 3 The adventurer
  • 4 Dungeon features
  • 5 Bestiary
  • 6 Objects
    • 6.1 Artifacts
    • 6.2 Amulets
    • 6.3 Food
    • 6.4 Weapons
    • 6.5 Tools
    • 6.6 Armor
    • 6.7 Potions
    • 6.8 Scrolls
    • 6.9 Wands
    • 6.10 Spellbooks
    • 6.11 Rings
    • 6.12 Stones
    • 6.13 Other items

Availability

The original Usenet posts are available from the Internet Archive, and are linked from this list of URLs.

Ali Harlow[1] has a NetHack 3.0.6 distribution at [2].

Significant changes

The NetHack 3.0 series is notable for its frequent releases, and NetHack 3.0.6 came out only weeks after NetHack 3.0.5. This is perhaps because NetHack 3.0.0 so vastly expanded the game that it contained many bugs.

Notable new features include:

  • The MS-DOS port now has support for overlays, allowing a full-featured game on MS-DOS for the first time in the 3.0 era.
  • Open doors have different symbols from closed ones.
  • Doors may be entered and exited diagonally. (Given how this interacts with shops, it seems likely to have disappeared rather quickly.)
  • Food may be eaten off the floor, and you no longer necessarily resume eating an interrupted meal.
  • Wielding non-weapons no longer grants intrinsics.
  • A new option, CLIPPING, allows playing on small windows.
  • The multiple demons are now controlled by INFERNO rather than HARD. Other features (not detailed here) are still controlled by HARD.
  • The / command now takes configurable characters into account.
  • Leprechauns switch letters with liches, and nymphs with nagas, so the more formidable monsters get the uppercase letters.
  • New monsters are tiger, grid bug, newt, gecko, iguana, lizard, and crocodile. The lizard corpse is no longer a distinct random object, but is obtained by killing a lizard.
  • There is one new object, a unicorn horn.
  • Drawbridges are improved.
  • Still more bug fixes.

The adventurer

The player may choose from these roles:

Role Alignment
Archeologist Lawful
Barbarian Chaotic
Cave-(wo)man Lawful
Elf Lawful
Healer Lawful
Knight Lawful
Priest(ess) Neutral
Rogue Chaotic
Samurai Lawful
Tourist Neutral
Valkyrie Chaotic
Wizard Neutral

All classes permit male and female adventurers, except the Valkyrie which must be female.

The adventurer has experience, hit points, magical energy, armor class, alignment, and the six major attributes. He may advance to experience level 30.

The initial pet is a little dog for Cavemen, a kitten for Wizards, and a random choice of the two for all others.

Dungeon features

The dungeon in NetHack 3.0.6 has no branches; there is one way up and one way down. The first 25 levels or so consist of rooms, and beyond that, the adventurer encounters the Castle and then mazes. The deepest dungeon level is 50.

Medusa appears as @ on the down-stairs of the level before the Castle. She does not have a special level, and is thus a snare for the unwary adventurer.

Dungeon levels below the Castle are designated as "Hell". Entering hell without fire resistance, or losing it once there, is an instadeath. This may happen by taking off an item that confers fire resistance (ring of fire resistance or red dragon scale mail), losing one's polymorph, or by being hit by a gremlin. One may still be saved if he has some other source of fire resistance. These levels have only up-stairs, and the only way to proceed beyond the first level after the Castle is by level teleportation.

Special rooms are:

  • throne room
  • swamp
  • vault
  • beehive
  • crypt
  • barracks
  • treasure zoo
  • temple
  • shop

Special dungeon features are:

  • pool
  • moat
  • drawbridge
  • door
  • ladder
  • fountain
  • throne
  • sink
  • altar

Traps are:

  • monsters disguised as statues
  • bear trap
  • arrow trap
  • dart trap
  • trapdoor
  • teleportation trap
  • pit
  • sleeping gas trap
  • magic trap
  • squeaky board
  • web
  • spiked pit
  • level teleporter
  • anti-magic field
  • rust trap
  • polymorph trap
  • land mine

The Amulet of Yendor is found in the possession of the Wizard of Yendor in a maze level. He is in a small room in the center of the maze, surrounded by water and accompanied by a hell hound and a vampire lord.

Fake Wizard rooms contain a random demon prince instead of the Wizard and a fake Amulet. If all demon princes have appeared, a demon lord appears instead; if all demon lords have appeared, the room contains a random ordinary demon. All eight modern named demons exist, but their modern lairs do not.

A wand of wishing is guaranteed in the Castle, in its modern position; but it lies exposed on the floor instead of being protected by a chest and Elbereth.

When ascending from level 1 with the Amulet of Yendor, one is transported immediately to the Astral Plane; the Elemental Planes do not yet exist. The Astral Plane is different from the modern game, having mazes and powerful monsters instead of the denizens of the modern version.
